title: Leicester hero Jamie Vardy admits stunning Liverpool display was response to critics over Claudio Ranieri exit
text:
Sport Leicester hero Jamie Vardy admits stunning Liverpool display was response to critics over Claudio Ranieri exit The England star netted his first league goals since December in the Foxes first game without Claudio Ranieri Share Leicester City's Jamie Vardy celebrates after the game (Photo: REUTERS) Share Get football   Thank you for subscribing! Could   
Double goal hero Jamie Vardy says Leicester's 3-1 thrashing of Liverpool was a reaction to player's "unfair criticism". 
The Foxes' players have been widely blamed for getting former manager Claudio Ranieri sacked last week. 
Ranieri was sacked last week just nine month after winning the Premier League but with the side just a point outside the relegation zone. 
Plenty blamed the title winners for not trying for their manager but Vardy has hit back at critics. Vardy gives Leicester the lead (Photo: Liverpool FC) Vardy celebrates his second and the Foxes third (Photo: Getty Images Europe) Read More Gary Neville baffled by Leicester City display - "Claudio Ranieri will be thinking where was that two weeks ago?" 
The striker, who scored his first league goal since December 10, said: "We've come under a lot of unfair stick whether that be in the press or online lately and what you saw out there is lads wanting to make a reaction. 
"The performance showed exactly that but now it is up for us to consistently do that and pick up as many points as possible. 
"To be honest I can't put my finger on why we haven't been playing like that. 
"We've done everything we've been asked to its just not been happening but tonight it all clicked." Danny Drinkwater thrashes in a wonder strike (Photo: REUTERS) Kasper Schmeichel jumps for joy as the Foxes won in the league for the first time in 2017 (Photo: REUTERS) Read More Leicester sack Ranieri and immediately become good at football again - Twitter's best theories and reactions 
Vardy looked back to his form of last season, and the hit man revealed what stand in chief Craig Shakespeare told him before the game. 
The former Fleetwood front man said: "Shakes before the game just told me to play a lot higher and do the weaknesses we thought that could hurt them. 
"We've been watching the video and hurt them tonight. Vardy nods in his second (Photo: Getty Images Europe) Craig Shakespeare was leading the team for the first time (Photo: Leicester City FC) 
"I've not been happy with the amount of goals this season but hopefully now i will push on with more to follow. 
"We just had to make sure we showed the fight and intensity. Win or lose as long as we got the performance right we could hold our heads high. 
"But with the performance we deserved the three points. 
"It's something to build on. The next game is more important now." poll loading Will Shakespeare become Leicester's next permanent manager? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
